content:
=== Game Rules ===
This is vgdl rule file:
BasicGame square_size=32
    SpriteSet
        background > Immovable img=oryx/space1 hidden=True
        base    > Immovable    color=WHITE img=oryx/planet
        avatar  > FlakAvatar   stype=sam img=oryx/spaceship1
        missile > Missile
            sam  > orientation=UP    color=BLUE singleton=True img=oryx/bullet1
            bomb > orientation=DOWN  color=RED  speed=0.5 img=oryx/bullet2
        alien   > Bomber       stype=bomb   prob=0.01  cooldown=3 speed=0.8
            alienGreen > img=oryx/alien3
            alienBlue > img=oryx/alien1
        portal  > invisible=True hidden=True
        	portalSlow  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienBlue  cooldown=16   total=20 img=portal
        	portalFast  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienGreen  cooldown=12   total=20 img=portal

    LevelMapping
        . > background
        0 > background base
        1 > background portalSlow
        2 > background portalFast
        A > background avatar

    TerminationSet
        SpriteCounter      stype=avatar               limit=0 win=False
        MultiSpriteCounter stype1=portal stype2=alien limit=0 win=True

    InteractionSet
        avatar  EOS  > stepBack
        alien   EOS  > turnAround
        missile EOS  > killSprite

        base bomb > killBoth
        base sam > killBoth scoreChange=1

        base   alien > killSprite
        avatar alien > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        avatar bomb  > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        alien  sam   > killSprite scoreChange=2

This is vgdl rule in natural language:
This game is essentially a classic arcade-style space shooter with elements reminiscent of Space Invaders. You control a spaceship (the "avatar") that fires projectiles (called “sam”) to take out enemy forces, while dodging incoming threats like enemy bombs and aliens.

Key points of the game:

• Genre & Setting
 – It’s a scrolling or fixed-screen space shooter with a space/planet backdrop.
 – You play as a spaceship flying in a space environment with a planetary “base” that has importance in the game relationships.

• Game Mechanics
 – The avatar (your spaceship) can shoot projectiles upward (the “sam” bullets) that destroy enemies.
 – There are enemy aliens that spawn from hidden portals. There are two types – one that’s slower (blue aliens coming from “portalFast”) and one that’s faster (green aliens from “portalSlow”), each with its own spawn timing.
 – Enemies have simple behaviors: aliens bounce and turn around when they hit the end-of-screen, and they drop bombs (bullets going downward) that threaten your ship or base.
 – There are also missiles and bombs flying around. Some enemy projectiles (bombs) when hitting the base will destroy both the bomb and the base.
 – The game area (level layout) is filled with obstacles or boundaries represented by numbers and letters, setting the stage for positioning and movement.

• Objectives & Win/Loss Conditions
 – The primary goal is to eliminate all enemy aliens spawned from the portals. When the “MultiSpriteCounter”—which monitors both the portals and their spawned aliens—reaches zero, the player wins.
 – At the same time, you must keep your avatar (spaceship) alive. If your spaceship is destroyed (its sprite count hits zero), the game ends in a loss.
 – Points are awarded and deducted based on interactions. For example, hitting an alien with your projectile (“sam”) gives you points (+2), whereas colliding with an alien or enemy bomb with your avatar subtracts points (–1).

• Overall Strategy
 – Stay agile: Keep your spaceship moving to avoid enemy aliens and dodging falling bombs.
 – Prioritize targets: Use your upward-firing “sam” projectiles to hit aliens before they get too close. A well-timed shot not only removes an enemy but also nets you points.
 – Control the pace: Since the aliens are continuously spawned from portals, it’s important to reduce their numbers quickly so that new threats don’t overwhelm you.
 – Balance offense and defense: While shooting enemies is important to gain points and clear the field, be mindful of your position relative to both enemy aliens and their bombs. Avoid risky collisions, since hitting an alien or bomb with your avatar will not only kill the enemy but also cost you points.
 – Protect assets: Although the game has a “base” that interacts with various sprites (like bombs and aliens), it’s often better to let enemy actions work in your favor (for example, enemies that reach the base might be automatically removed) rather than risk losing your own avatar in a scramble.
 – Adapt to enemy patterns: Aliens will turn around when they hit screen edges, so use this to predict their movement and plan your shots accordingly.

In short, by combining precise shooting with careful movement, you can gradually clear the screen of enemy aliens spawned from the hidden portals and secure a win. Stay alert, keep your score positive by avoiding collisions, and focus on eliminating threats efficiently.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT

Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
background -> '.'
background base -> '0'
background portalSlow -> '1'
background portalFast -> '2'
alienBlue -> '@'
base -> '#'
sam -> '$'
alienBlue bomb -> '%'
